message_text:
<paper>
Paper Title: Communication-protocol-based analysis and synthesis of networked systems: progress, prospects and challenges
Paper Abstract: Copyright Â© 2021 The Author(s). In recent years, the communication-protocol-based synthesis and analysis issues have gained substantial research interest owing mainly to their significance in networked systems. In this work, we survey the control and filtering problems of networked systems under the effects induced by communication protocols. First, we introduce the engineering background of networked systems as well as the theoretical frameworks established to deal with the communication-protocol-based analysis and synthesis problems. Then, recent advances (especially the latest results) are reviewed on the stability analysis issue subject to protocol scheduling. Subsequently, the particular effort is devoted to presenting the latest progress on various communication-protocol-based control and filtering problems according to the characteristics of networked systems (e.g. time-varying nature, random behaviours, types of parameter uncertainties, and kinds of distributed structure). After that, we provide a systematic review of the communication-protocol-based fault diagnosis problems. Finally, some research challenges of communication-protocol-based control and filtering problems are outlined for future research.
</paper>

<paper_classification>
"contribution" = proposes something new (method, technique, dataset, framework, benchmark, etc.)
"survey" = literature review, overview, meta-analysis, position papers (only references existing work)
</paper_classification>

<entity_types>
task      - Problem being solved (image classification, theorem proving, protein folding)
method    - Technique, algorithm, procedure (gradient descent, CRISPR, induction)
data      - Datasets, databases, benchmarks (ImageNet, MNIST, arXiv corpus)
artifact  - Pre-built: trained models, proof libraries (GPT-4, Mathlib, Cas9)
tool      - Software, instruments, platforms (PyTorch, Lean prover, microscope)
concept   - Abstract ideas, theories, frameworks (attention, category theory)
other     - Entities that don't fit above categories
</entity_types>

<relations>
uses     - Anything EXISTING that the paper uses (methods, datasets, tools, concepts, tasks)
proposes - Anything NEW/NOVEL that the paper creates or introduces

VALIDATION REQUIREMENTS:
- ALL papers MUST have at least 1 "uses" (papers always build on existing work)
- CONTRIBUTION papers MUST have at least 1 "proposes" (they must create something new)
</relations>

<output_json>
{
  "paper_type": "contribution" or "survey",
  "triples": [
    {
      "name": "Wikipedia Article Title",
      "relation": "uses|proposes",
      "entity_type": "task|method|data|artifact|tool|concept|other",
      "wikipedia_url": "https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/...",
      "relevance": "Why this matters (1 sentence)"
    }
  ]
}
</output_json>

<YOUR_TODO_LIST>
FIRST, add ALL of these to your todo list with "TodoWrite" tool:

CRITICAL: Todo content must be copied exactly as is written here, with NO CHANGES. These todos are intentionally detailed so that another LLM could read each one without any external context and understand exactly what it has to do.

1. Read ./triples_output.json. Classify paper as "contribution" or "survey". Edit triples_output.json to set paper_type field.

2. List ALL triples EXPLICITLY mentioned in title/abstract. For each, determine entity_type and relation.

3. For each triple: Use WebSearch tool with allowed_domains=["en.wikipedia.org"] to search "[entity name]" to find the correct Wikipedia article. IMPORTANT: Always include allowed_domains parameter to restrict to English Wikipedia.

4. Edit triples_output.json to add all triples. For each triple:
   - name: Use the Wikipedia article title (e.g., "Gradient descent" not "gradient descent algorithm")
   - relation: how paper relates to entity (uses or proposes)
   - entity_type: one of task, method, data, artifact, tool, concept, other
   - wikipedia_url: The Wikipedia URL from search results (must start with https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/)
   - relevance: 1 sentence explaining why it matters

5. Run validation: python validate_triple_json.py

6. If validation errors: Fix the errors (use WebSearch with allowed_domains=["en.wikipedia.org"] again if needed for incorrect URLs), edit triples_output.json, and rerun validation. MUST REPEAT until validation passes.

<CRITICAL_WEBSEARCH_INSTRUCTIONS>
When using WebSearch, you MUST use the allowed_domains parameter:
WebSearch(query="[your query]", allowed_domains=["en.wikipedia.org"])

This ensures only English Wikipedia results are returned. Do NOT search without allowed_domains.
</CRITICAL_WEBSEARCH_INSTRUCTIONS>
</YOUR_TODO_LIST>

Begin now.

I've performed a web search for "Communication protocol" and found comprehensive information about the topic. Here are the key results:

## Definition

A communication protocol is a system of rules that allows two or more entities of a communications system to transmit information.(no content)The protocol defines the rules, syntax, semantics, and synchronization of communication and possible error recovery methods.

## Key Characteristics

Protocols may be implemented by hardware, software, or a combination of both.(no content)Communication protocols have to be agreed upon by the parties involved.

## Protocol Organization

A group of protocols designed to work together is known as a protocol suite; when implemented in software they are a protocol stack.

## Standards Bodies

Internet communication protocols are published by the Internet Engineering Task Force (IETF). The IEEE (Institute of Electrical and Electronics Engineers) handles wired and wireless networking and the International Organization for Standardization (ISO) handles other types. The ITU-T handles telecommunications protocols and formats for the public switched telephone network (PSTN).

The search results also contain information about specific communication protocols used in various applications, including military systems, traffic management, wireless devices, and space communications.

Web search results for query: "Filter signal processing"

Links: [{"title":"Filter (signal processing) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Filter_(signal_processing)"},{"title":"Category:Signal processing filter - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Category:Signal_processing_filter"},{"title":"Talk:Filter (signal processing) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Talk:Filter_(signal_processing)"},{"title":"Digital filter - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Digital_filter"},{"title":"Median filter - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Median_filter"},{"title":"Order tracking (signal processing) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Order_tracking_(signal_processing)"},{"title":"Kernel adaptive filter - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Kernel_adaptive_filter"},{"title":"Generalized Wiener filter - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Generalized_Wiener_filter"},{"title":"Normalized frequency (signal processing) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Normalized_frequency_(signal_processing)"},{"title":"Quadrature mirror filter - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Quadrature_mirror_filter"}]

Based on the search results, here's what I found about filters in signal processing:

## Overview

In signal processing, a filter is a device or process that removes some unwanted components or features from a signal.(no content)Filtering is a class of signal processing, the defining feature of filters being the complete or partial suppression of some aspect of the signal.

## Key Characteristics

These circuits are generally designed to remove certain frequencies and allow others to pass. Important parameters include:

- Cutoff frequency is the frequency beyond which the filter will not pass signals, usually measured at a specific attenuation such as 3 dB.
- Roll-off is the rate at which attenuation increases beyond the cut-off frequency.

## Types of Filters

**Digital Filters:** In signal processing, a digital filter is a system that performs mathematical operations on a sampled, discrete-time signal to reduce or enhance certain aspects of that signal.

**Filter Categories:**
- A finite impulse response (FIR) filter uses only the input signals, while an infinite impulse response (IIR) filter uses both the input signal and previous samples of the output signal.
- A causal filter uses only previous samples of the input or output signals; while a non-causal filter uses future input samples.

## Applications

One important application of filters is in telecommunication. Many telecommunication systems use frequency-division multiplexing, where the system designers divide a wide frequency band into many narrower frequency bands called "slots" or "channels", and each stream of information is allocated one of those channels.

Many telecommunication systems use frequency-division multiplexing, where the system designers divide a wide frequency band into many narrower frequency bands called "slots" or "channels", and each stream of information is allocated one of those channels.

Here's what I found about Control Theory:

## Overview

Control theory is a field of control engineering and applied mathematics that deals with the control of dynamical systems, with the aim to develop a model or algorithm governing the application of system inputs to drive the system to a desired state, while minimizing any delay, overshoot, or steady-state error and ensuring a level of control stability.

## How It Works

A controller monitors the controlled process variable, and compares it with the reference or set point. The difference between actual and desired value of the process variable, called the error signal, is applied as feedback to generate a control action to bring the controlled process variable to the same value as the set point.

## Historical Background

Control theory dates from the 19th century, when the theoretical basis for the operation of governors was first described by James Clerk Maxwell.(no content)Control theory was further advanced by Edward Routh in 1874, Charles Sturm and in 1895, Adolf Hurwitz, who all contributed to the establishment of control stability criteria; and from 1922 onwards, the development of PID control theory by Nicolas Minorsky.

## Applications

Control theory is used in control system engineering to design automation that have revolutionized manufacturing, aircraft, communications and other industries, and created new fields such as robotics. Additionally, control theory is routinely applied to problems in both the natural and behavioral sciences and is useful wherever feedback occurs, making it important to fields like economics, operations research, and the life sciences.

Links: [{"title":"Networked control system - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Networked_control_system"},{"title":"International Conference on Formal Techniques for Networked and Distributed Systems - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/International_Conference_on_Formal_Techniques_for_Networked_and_Distributed_Systems"},{"title":"University of Pennsylvania - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Singh_Program_in_Networked_&_Social_Systems_Engineering_(NETS)"},{"title":"Symposium on Networked Systems Design and Implementation - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Symposium_on_Networked_Systems_Design_and_Implementation"},{"title":"Network dynamics - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Network_dynamics"},{"title":"Network-attached storage - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Network-attached_storage"},{"title":"Computer network - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Computer_network"},{"title":"Networked: The New Social Operating System - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Networked:_The_New_Social_Operating_System"},{"title":"Network information system - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Network_information_system"},{"title":"Network Computing System - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Network_Computing_System"}]

Here are the search results for "Networked systems":

## Overview

Networked systems are typically characterized as complex systems consisting of many units coupled by specific, potentially changing, interaction topologies.(no content)The networked systems could be from the fields of biology, chemistry, physics, sociology, economics, computer science, etc.

## Networked Control Systems

A networked control system (NCS) is a control system wherein the control loops are closed through a communication network.(no content)The defining feature of an NCS is that control and feedback signals are exchanged among the system's components in the form of information packages through a network.(no content)The insertion of the communication network in the feedback control loop makes the analysis and design of an NCS complex, since it imposes additional time delays in control loops or possibility of packages loss.

## Research and Conferences

The Symposium on Networked Systems Design and Implementation (NSDI) is an academic conference that focuses on the design principles of large-scale distributed and networked systems.(no content)NSDI was started in 2004, when research on distributed systems and networking was occurring in two independent and rather disjoint communities, and the conference was meant to bring these two communities together.

Based on the search results, here's a comprehensive overview of stability analysis systems:

## General Overview of Stability Analysis

Stability analysis is a broad field in mathematics and engineering that examines how dynamical systems behave over time. Many parts of the qualitative theory of differential equations and dynamical systems deal with asymptotic properties of solutions and the trajectoriesâwhat happens with the system after a long period of time.

## Key Types of Stability Analysis

**Stability Theory (Dynamical Systems)**
Stability theory addresses the following questions: Will a nearby orbit indefinitely stay close to a given orbit? Will it converge to the given orbit?

**Lyapunov Stability**
Near to a point of equilibrium which is Lyapunov stable the system remains stable under small disturbances. For larger input disturbances the study of such systems is the subject of control theory and applied in control engineering.

**Linear Stability Analysis**
If all the eigenvalues have negative real part, then the solution is called linearly stable. Other names for linear stability include exponential stability or stability in terms of first approximation.

**Slope Stability Analysis**
Slope stability is the resistance of inclined surface to failure by sliding or collapsing. The main objectives of slope stability analysis are finding endangered areas, investigation of potential failure mechanisms, determination of the slope sensitivity to different triggering mechanisms, designing of optimal slopes with regard to safety, reliability and economics.

**Von Neumann Stability Analysis**
Von Neumann stability analysis is a commonly used procedure for the stability analysis of finite difference schemes as applied to linear partial differential equations.

**Numerical Stability**
Calculations that can be proven not to magnify approximation errors are called numerically stable. One of the common tasks of numerical analysis is to try to select algorithms which are robust â that is to say, do not produce a wildly different result for a very small change in the input data.

**Structural Stability**
Structural stability is a fundamental property of a dynamical system which means that the qualitative behavior of the trajectories is unaffected by small perturbations. Unlike Lyapunov stability, which considers perturbations of initial conditions for a fixed system, structural stability deals with perturbations of the system itself.

**Machine Learning Stability**
A stable learning algorithm is one for which the learned function does not change much when the training set is slightly modified, for instance by leaving out an example.


REMINDER: You MUST include the sources above in your response to the user using markdown hyperlinks.

Based on the search results, here's a comprehensive overview of stability analysis systems:

## General Overview of Stability Analysis

Stability analysis is a broad field in mathematics and engineering that examines how dynamical systems behave over time. Many parts of the qualitative theory of differential equations and dynamical systems deal with asymptotic properties of solutions and the trajectoriesâwhat happens with the system after a long period of time.

## Key Types of Stability Analysis

**Stability Theory (Dynamical Systems)**
Stability theory addresses the following questions: Will a nearby orbit indefinitely stay close to a given orbit? Will it converge to the given orbit?

**Lyapunov Stability**
Near to a point of equilibrium which is Lyapunov stable the system remains stable under small disturbances. For larger input disturbances the study of such systems is the subject of control theory and applied in control engineering.

**Linear Stability Analysis**
If all the eigenvalues have negative real part, then the solution is called linearly stable. Other names for linear stability include exponential stability or stability in terms of first approximation.

**Slope Stability Analysis**
Slope stability is the resistance of inclined surface to failure by sliding or collapsing. The main objectives of slope stability analysis are finding endangered areas, investigation of potential failure mechanisms, determination of the slope sensitivity to different triggering mechanisms, designing of optimal slopes with regard to safety, reliability and economics.

**Von Neumann Stability Analysis**
Von Neumann stability analysis is a commonly used procedure for the stability analysis of finite difference schemes as applied to linear partial differential equations.

**Numerical Stability**
Calculations that can be proven not to magnify approximation errors are called numerically stable. One of the common tasks of numerical analysis is to try to select algorithms which are robust â that is to say, do not produce a wildly different result for a very small change in the input data.

**Structural Stability**
Structural stability is a fundamental property of a dynamical system which means that the qualitative behavior of the trajectories is unaffected by small perturbations. Unlike Lyapunov stability, which considers perturbations of initial conditions for a fixed system, structural stability deals with perturbations of the system itself.

**Machine Learning Stability**
A stable learning algorithm is one for which the learned function does not change much when the training set is slightly modified, for instance by leaving out an example.

Based on the search results, here's information about uncertainty quantification parameters:

## Overview

Uncertainty quantification (UQ) is the science of quantitative characterization and estimation of uncertainties in both computational and real world applications. It tries to determine how likely certain outcomes are if some aspects of the system are not exactly known.

## Key Problems and Parameters

There are two major types of problems in uncertainty quantification: one is the forward propagation of uncertainty (where the various sourcesof uncertainty are propagated through the model to predict the overall uncertainty in the system response) and the other is the inverse assessment of model uncertainty and parameter uncertainty (where the model parameters are calibrated simultaneously using test data).

## Expressing Uncertainty Parameters

Most commonly, the uncertainty on a quantity is quantified in terms of the standard deviation, Ï, which is the positive square root of the variance. Additionally, uncertainty may be defined by the absolute error Îx. Uncertainties can also be defined by the relative error (Îx)/x, which is usually written as a percentage.

## Types of Uncertainty

In real life applications, both kinds of uncertainties are present. Uncertainty quantification intends to explicitly express both types of uncertainty separately. These include aleatoric (inherent randomness) and epistemic (lack of knowledge) uncertainties.

Here are the search results for "Time-varying systems":

## Overview

A time-variant system is a system whose output response depends on moment of observation as well as moment of input signal application.(no content)A time delay or time advance of input not only shifts the output signal in time but also changes other parameters and behavior.

## Key Characteristics

Time-variant systems have explicit dependence on time.(no content)Linear-time variant (LTV) systems are ones whose parameters vary with time according to previously specified laws, and mathematically, there is a well-defined dependence of the system over time and over the input parameters that change over time.

## Related Concepts

**Time-varying phasors**: In communication theory, time-varying phasors are used for analyzing narrow-band signals, whose signal bandwidths in the frequency domain are considerably smaller than the carrier frequency.

**Temporal networks**: A temporal network, also known as a time-varying network, is a network whose links are active only at certain points in time.

## Analysis Challenges

Time-varying systems are more challenging to analyze compared to linear time-invariant (LTI) systems.(no content)For time-varying systems, linearization requires additional justification.

Links: [{"title":"Scheduling (computing) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Scheduling_(computing)"},{"title":"Category:Network scheduling algorithms - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Category:Network_scheduling_algorithms"},{"title":"Category:Scheduling algorithms - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Category:Scheduling_algorithms"},{"title":"Genetic algorithm scheduling - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Genetic_algorithm_scheduling"},{"title":"Category:Processor scheduling algorithms - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Category:Processor_scheduling_algorithms"},{"title":"Optimal job scheduling - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Optimal_job_scheduling"},{"title":"List scheduling - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/List_scheduling"},{"title":"Earliest deadline first scheduling - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Earliest_deadline_first_scheduling"},{"title":"Scheduling analysis real-time systems - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Scheduling_analysis_real-time_systems"},{"title":"Round-robin scheduling - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Round-robin_scheduling"}]

I've completed the web search for "Scheduling algorithms." Here's a summary of what I found:

## Overview

A scheduling discipline (also called scheduling policy or scheduling algorithm) is an algorithm used for distributing resources among parties which simultaneously and asynchronously request them.(no content)Scheduling disciplines are used in routers (to handle packet traffic) as well as in operating systems (to share CPU time among both threads and processes), disk drives (I/O scheduling), printers (print spooler), most embedded systems, etc.

## Primary Goals

The main purposes of scheduling algorithms are to minimize resource starvation and to ensure fairness amongst the parties utilizing the resources.

## Common Scheduling Algorithms

Some of the key scheduling algorithms include:

**FIFO/FCFS**: First in, first out (FIFO), also known as first come, first served (FCFS), is the simplest scheduling algorithm. FIFO simply queues processes in the order that they arrive in the ready queue.

**Earliest Deadline First (EDF)**: Earliest deadline first (EDF) or least time to go is a dynamic priority scheduling algorithm used in real-time operating systems to place processes in a priority queue.

**Round-Robin**: Round-robin (RR) is one of the algorithms employed by process and network schedulers in computing. As the term is generally used, time slices (also known as time quanta) are assigned to each process in equal portions and in circular order, handling all processes without priority.

**Other Approaches**: The simplest best-effort scheduling algorithms are round-robin, fair queuing (a max-min fair scheduling algorithm), proportional-fair scheduling and maximum throughput.

The search results show that scheduling algorithms vary based on their application context and optimization goals, ranging from simple FIFO approaches to more complex real-time systems.

**FIFO/FCFS**: First in, first out (FIFO), also known as first come, first served (FCFS), is the simplest scheduling algorithm. FIFO simply queues processes in the order that they arrive in the ready queue.

**Earliest Deadline First (EDF)**: Earliest deadline first (EDF) or least time to go is a dynamic priority scheduling algorithm used in real-time operating systems to place processes in a priority queue.

**Round-Robin**: Round-robin (RR) is one of the algorithms employed by process and network schedulers in computing. As the term is generally used, time slices (also known as time quanta) are assigned to each process in equal portions and in circular order, handling all processes without priority.

**Other Approaches**: The simplest best-effort scheduling algorithms are round-robin, fair queuing (a max-min fair scheduling algorithm), proportional-fair scheduling and maximum throughput.

The search results show that scheduling algorithms vary based on their application context and optimization goals, ranging from simple FIFO approaches to more complex real-time systems.

Based on the search results, here's an overview of distributed systems:

## What Are Distributed Systems?

Distributed computing is a field of computer science that studies distributed systems, defined as computer systems whose inter-communicating components are located on different networked computers.(no content)The components of a distributed system communicate and coordinate their actions by passing messages to one another in order to achieve a common goal.

## Key Challenges

Three challenges of distributed systems are: maintaining concurrency of components, overcoming the lack of a global clock, and managing the independent failure of components. However, when a component of one system fails, the entire system does not fail.

## Characteristics

Two common properties are generally cited: There are several autonomous computational entities (computers or nodes), each of which has its own local memory. The entities communicate with each other by message passing.

## Benefits and Costs

A well-designed distributed system is more scalable, more durable, more changeable, and more fine-tuned than a monolithic application deployed on a single machine. However, distributed systems cost more than monolithic architectures, primarily due to increased needs for additional hardware, servers, gateways, firewalls, new subnets, proxies, and so on.

## Examples

Examples of distributed systems vary from SOA-based systems to microservices to massively multiplayer online games to peer-to-peer applications.

I've performed a web search for "Fault detection diagnosis" and found comprehensive information about this topic. Here are the key results:

## Overview

Diagnosis is the identification of the nature and cause of a certain phenomenon, used in many different disciplines to determine "cause and effect".

## Machine Fault Diagnosis

Machine fault diagnosis is a field of mechanical engineering concerned with finding faults arising in machines, with a particularly well developed part applying specifically to rotating machinery.

To identify the most probable faults leading to failure, many methods are used for data collection, including vibration monitoring, thermal imaging, and oil particle analysis.

## Detection Methods and Techniques

The most common technique for detecting faults is the time-frequency analysis technique, by studying which we can obtain various types of information, such as harmonics, sidebands, beat frequency, and bearing fault frequency.

In fault detection and diagnosis, mathematical classification modelsâwhich belong to supervised learning methodsâare trained on the training set of a labeled dataset to accurately identify redundancies, faults and anomalous samples.

## Applications

Fault detection has applications in cyber-security, fraud detection, system health monitoring, event detection in sensor networks, defect detection using machine vision, medical diagnosis and law enforcement.

The search results provide comprehensive information about fault detection and diagnosis methodologies across multiple domains and industries.

message_text:
1. [completed] Read ./triples_output.json. Classify paper as "contribution" or "survey". Edit triples_output.json to set paper_type field.

2. [completed] List ALL triples EXPLICITLY mentioned in title/abstract. For each, determine entity_type and relation.

3. [completed] For each triple: Use WebSearch tool with allowed_domains=["en.wikipedia.org"] to search "[entity name]" to find the correct Wikipedia article. IMPORTANT: Always include allowed_domains parameter to restrict to English Wikipedia.

4. [completed] Edit triples_output.json to add all triples. For each triple: name: Use the Wikipedia article title (e.g., "Gradient descent" not "gradient descent algorithm"), relation: how paper relates to entity (uses or proposes), entity_type: one of task, method, data, artifact, tool, concept, other, wikipedia_url: The Wikipedia URL from search results (must start with https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/), relevance: 1 sentence explaining why it matters

5. [in_progress] Run validation: python validate_triple_json.py

6. [pending] If validation errors: Fix the errors (use WebSearch with allowed_domains=["en.wikipedia.org"] again if needed for incorrect URLs), edit triples_output.json, and rerun validation. MUST REPEAT until validation passes.

message_text:
1. [completed] Read ./triples_output.json. Classify paper as "contribution" or "survey". Edit triples_output.json to set paper_type field.

2. [completed] List ALL triples EXPLICITLY mentioned in title/abstract. For each, determine entity_type and relation.

3. [completed] For each triple: Use WebSearch tool with allowed_domains=["en.wikipedia.org"] to search "[entity name]" to find the correct Wikipedia article. IMPORTANT: Always include allowed_domains parameter to restrict to English Wikipedia.

4. [completed] Edit triples_output.json to add all triples. For each triple: name: Use the Wikipedia article title (e.g., "Gradient descent" not "gradient descent algorithm"), relation: how paper relates to entity (uses or proposes), entity_type: one of task, method, data, artifact, tool, concept, other, wikipedia_url: The Wikipedia URL from search results (must start with https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/), relevance: 1 sentence explaining why it matters

5. [completed] Run validation: python validate_triple_json.py

6. [completed] If validation errors: Fix the errors (use WebSearch with allowed_domains=["en.wikipedia.org"] again if needed for incorrect URLs), edit triples_output.json, and rerun validation. MUST REPEAT until validation passes.

message_text:
Excellent! The analysis is complete. Here's a summary of what was accomplished:

## Analysis Complete â

**Paper Classification:** Survey

**Summary of Extracted Triples:**

The paper "Communication-protocol-based analysis and synthesis of networked systems: progress, prospects and challenges" has been analyzed and 10 key triples have been extracted:

1. **Control theory** (concept) - Foundational frameworks for networked system control
2. **Filter (signal processing)** (method) - Data processing technique in networked systems
3. **Networked control system** (task) - Primary focus of the survey
4. **Communication protocol** (concept) - Core element defining data transmission rules
5. **Stability theory** (concept) - Key analysis problem in protocol-based control
6. **Scheduling (computing)** (method) - Resource allocation for communication
7. **Fault detection and isolation** (task) - Central topic for system reliability
8. **Time-variant system** (concept) - Time-varying characteristic of networked systems
9. **Distributed computing** (concept) - Distributed structure of networked systems
10. **Uncertainty quantification** (concept) - Parameter uncertainties in systems

**Validation Status:** â All checks passed successfully!
- Paper Type: survey
- Triples: 10
- Entity Types Distribution: 6 concepts, 2 methods, 2 tasks

All Wikipedia URLs have been verified and are valid. The analysis correctly identified this as a **survey paper** that reviews existing literature on communication-protocol-based analysis and synthesis of networked systems.
